# Hungarian is awesome

![magyar](https://cdn2.traveler.es/uploads/images/thumbs/es/trav/3/s/2017/37/budapest_todo_lo_que_tienes_que_hacer_en_la_ciudad_7749_940x627.jpg)

## Some fascinating facts about Hungarian language

- The longest word in hungarian is “megszentségteleníthetetlenségeskedéseitekért” which roughly means “for your (plural) continous (recurring) behavior of not being able to be desecrated” or something like that…
- If you say “Whole wanna new see?” it actually makes sence in Hungarian: it has a really close pronanciation to “Hol van a nyuszi?” which means “Where is the bunny?”
- We have some words with the exact same spelling which can mean different things. E.g. “ég” can mean “sky” or “it is on fire” or “it burns” (e.g. a rash) or “it is lit” (like a light bulb or candle). To confuse you more “égő” which is derived from “ég” can mean “light bulb” or “burning” or it can be a slang for “embarassing”. It is not the same as “ég ő” which could mean she/he is on fire, burning or embarassed.
- The phrase “The sun is shining” in Hungarian is “Süt a nap” which litteraly means “The sun is baking”
- Magyarország (Hungary) means “Magyar country” in accurate translation. Most of the country names have “ország” (country) in them in Hungarian. E.g. Oroszország - Russian country, Németország - German country etc.
- Although Hungary is a small country we still have different dialects (dialect of Budapest, Debrecen, Somogy etc.). E.g. “lower” (as sg is at a lower location in comparison to sg else) in Hungarian can be “lejjebb” or “lentebb” depending on the dialect. Or the phrase “we will see” can be “Majd meglátjuk” (we will see) or “Majd meglátszik” (it will show).
- We use so many “e”-s in our language that we invented “Eszperente” (not Esperanto!) which is a language game where you have to use words only with “e” in them. The strangest example is a sentence made up using only “e”-s and “t”-s: “Te tetted e tettetett tettet te tettetett tettek tettese.” which means “You did this pretended act, you, the doer of pretended acts.” The trick of using so many “e”-s is that we pronounce it two ways, there is a more closed and high and a more open and low version.
- If you learned the Hungarian alphabet you can read Hungarian or write it down as we write every word as we pronounce it. The only confusion in writing is around “j” and “ly” which are both the same sound (like Y in yo-yo) and around “e” as indicated above in reading. There are actually a lot of Hungarians who don’t know when to use “ly” or “j” so don’t worry if you confuse them. The “rule” is if you can say the word with “l” and you get the same meaning in old Hungarian, then it is written with “ly” (e.g. luk -lyuk, both means hole). If it has a different meaning than it is “j” (e.g. játszik which means sy is playing - látszik which means sg is showing).
- Hungarians use/write their names with family name first (like Smith John) not the other way around. Sometimes it is confusing for foreigners since we also say our name in English if we speak English. My family name for example is “Tancsa” and I was addressed several times in emails like “Hi Tancsa,” which is wierd but still sweet as the writer tried to be attentive. A lot of English names has their Hungarian version. E.g. John above would be called “Kovács János” which is actually the Hungarian version of John Doe as the most frequent name in Hungary. Some other forename examples are: Erick - Erik, Richard - Rihárd, Henry - Henrik, Gabriel - Gábriel, Tomas - Tamás, Rachel - Ráhel, Emily - Emília, Olive - Olívia, Anne - Anna etc.
